content.question: A student conducts an experiment to measure the specific heat capacity, <math alttext="c" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, of a metal. The student heats <math alttext="20.0 grams" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>20.0</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mtext>g</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> of the metal, adds the heated metal to a calorimeter containing <math alttext="100.0 grams" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of water initially at <math alttext="18.5 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18.5</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the mixture comes to thermal equilibrium at <math alttext="19.7 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>19.7</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following experimental errors best explains why the value of <math alttext="c" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> calculated from the data is smaller than the accepted value for the metal?

choices.label: The heated metal transfers some thermal energy to the surrounding air before it contacts the water in the calorimeter.
The warmer air in the laboratory transfers thermal energy into the colder water in the calorimeter.

An improperly calibrated balance results in more than <math alttext="20.0 grams" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of metal being used in the experiment.

An improperly calibrated balance results in less than <math alttext="100.0 grams" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of water being used in the experiment.

content.answer: The heated metal transfers some thermal energy to the surrounding air before it contacts the water in the calorimeter.

skill.text: 2.E: Identify or describe potential sources of experimental error.
